While up slightly from the previous survey, that forecast is still down from the $72 a barrel in the October survey last year (para. 13-14). Kantchev, G. (2017). The Iraqi government has encouraged foreign governments to stop importing kurdish crude, however the KRG “has been selling crude through intermediators such as trading houses like Vitol…”
“Turkey has shown little intention to close the pipeline. It benefits from tariffs on the pipeline and is positioning itself as a reliable energy corridor for exports from the Middle East and Russia.”

Erdogan recently said “Russia and Turkey agreed that the territorial integrity of Iraq and neighbouring Syria must be preserved.” Though Putin gave no opinion on the independence vote, saying “Moscow’s position has been set out by the foreign ministry which said it respected the Kurd’s “national striving” but supported the sovereignty, unity and territorial integrity of Iraq”. The Prime Minister has also agreed with his “Iraqi counterpart to coordinate economic and trade relations with the central government, after Abadi’s government took control of border crossings with Turkey.” (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-kurds-referendum-turke/turkey-iran-iraq-may-meet-to-discuss-kurdish-iraqi-referendum-turkey-pm-idUSKCN1C31P5)  However, the price rally may be short lived due to U.S. recovery and strengthening U.S. dollar:

Oil Pulls Back After Topping $50 a Barrel Investors weighing evidence that the world stock overhang is finally falling against rising OPEC production Sider and McFarlane (2017) Aug 11, states that: Oil futures fell Thursday, pulling back after topping $50 a barrel as investors weighed evidence that the world stock overhang is finally falling against rising OPEC production. U.S. crude futures settled down 97 cents, or 1.96%, at $48.50 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest settlement level since July 25. Brent crude, the global oil benchmark, fell 80 cents, or 1.52%, to $51.90 a barrel after hitting an 11-week high on London’s ICE Futures exchange. The Brent front-month contract traded at a premium to the second-month, a market configuration known as backwardation, indicating a tightening in supplies available for immediate delivery. Oil traded in a wide range Thursday—the U.S. benchmark rose as high as $50.22 during the day, but sold off sharply in the final minutes of trading. Analysts and traders attributed the big swings partly to the influence of computer-algorithm based trading systems, which have become more influential in the oil market this year. “This well take every algorithm out there that’s been bullish to neutral or sell,” said Donald Morton, senior vice president at Herbert J. Sims & Co. who oversees an energy trading desk. “It’s not a good sign for the short-term market” (para. 1-5). Sider, A. & McFarlane, S. (2017). Oil Pulls Back After Topping $50 a Barrel. Venezuela Rebellion Could Send Oil To $80 Cunningham (2017) Aug 07, states that: Venezuela’s deteriorating crisis is “going to be the biggest geopolitical story to watch in the oil markets," according to Helima Croft of RBC Capital Markets. 
The economic, political and security situation in Venezuela has been frightening for quite a while, but things continue to grow worse. The new “constituent assembly,” put together to rewrite the constitution, is seen by most as an attempt to erode the nation’s democracy and consolidate power in the hands of the president (para. 1-2) 
But even if Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro manages to maintain power and push through a new constitution that defangs any restraints on his grip, he won’t be able to outrun the spiraling economic crisis. Perhaps the most visible economic issue is the debt payments that fall due this year. Venezuela has $5 billion in debt maturing before the year is out – both in sovereign bonds and in debt payments by state-owned oil company PDVSA (para. 4). 
That is an alarming figure given that the government has an estimated $3 billion in cash reserves, according to S&P Global Ratings, a paltry sum that means a default in the next few months is more likely than not. Venezuela has to pay $725 million in debt payments this month, although the problem gets really serious in October and November, when a combined $3.6 billion in debt must be paid to bondholders. The value of PDVSA’s bonds has plunged in recent weeks (para. 4-6). The probability of default within 12 months, based on the value of credit-default swaps on Venezuelan debt, has an implied rate of 70 percent, according to the WSJ (para. 9). Cunningham, N. (2017). US shale oil production is on track to reach 9.9 million bls/d by the end of 2018, EXCEEDING our peak in 1970. US imports of crude will likely remain around 250 million bls/year, or about 7000 bls/d, with most of it coming from either Canada or Latin America. On the whole, we are almost net-neutral in terms of crude oil import-export. However, shale oil production is slated to increase through 2019, despite the low cost per barrel. First, 40% of US drillers is now funding by private investors, decreasing the pressure to turn an early profit. Second, many producers have locked-in contracts to guarantee prices, despite increases in production. Third, due to increased efficiencies, 60% of US shale drills are now profitable within a range of $35-55/bl. As more drills come on line through 2017 and into 2018, the US will be better poised to increase production in the event of additional OPEC cuts, taking market share. This production will exert downward pressure on the price of Brent crude. Thus, the real question is whether the price will be over or under $50 by the end of year. Right now, I believe it is 40/60% since most US wells will break even or be slightly profitable there. I do not think there is a realistic chance for it to fall below $40. A six-month effort led by Saudi Arabia and Russia to reduce the glut in global oil markets has flopped. So today, in Vienna, OPEC will try its luck again, extending output cuts, probably for another nine months. It’s unlikely to spark a big rally. Inventories may have peaked, but so has OPEC discipline: even if Iraq endorses a deal, it will probably cheat. Nigeria and Libya, both exempt from the cuts, are increasing production. And America’s shale output is surging. To push oil well above $50 a barrel, OPEC and non-OPEC suppliers would have to make more drastic cuts. Saudi Arabia has pledged to do “whatever it takes” to reduce stocks; it wants higher prices to support the forthcoming initial public offering of Aramco, the state-owned producer. It may also need to influence the futures markets so that shale producers stop hedging their output. OPEC needs crafty new tactics to beat the wily frackers

“Iraq’s oil minister said his country could raise output to 5mb/d in the second half of 2017. US shale production continues to rise with new oil rigs.  “US oil producers have added 315 oil rigs since last May. Nearly half of those rigs are located in the Permian Basin alone, which has almost tripled its rig count over the past year, according Baker Hughes” (http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/20/investing/permian-basin-oil-texas-shale-opec/) The article from CNN also states “By comparison, production is shrinking in the Eagle Ford and Bakken”. The data provided by the EIA shows the oil production in the Permian Region is up 79tb/d in March (https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/drilling/pdf/permian.pdf), contrary to the CNN article, production in Eagle Ford is up 28tb/d. (https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/drilling/pdf/eagleford.pdf)  However, Bakken oil production is down 10tb/d (March 2017), which, if it continues to decline, will partially offset the rise in production from the other regions. (https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/drilling/pdf/bakken.pdf). This is not enough to increase prices to the level OPEC was hoping for but it will help in the grand scheme of things.  It is possible the US drillers will realise its not sustainable to be drilling at the current rate. “If oil prices stay this low, it will be hard to justify the Permian’s sky-high land prices. Plus oil producers there are already complaining about rising prices for services” (http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/20/investing/permian-basin-oil-texas-shale-opec/)  There is also talk about OPEC extending the deal. “Oil prices edges higher on Tuesday, helped by expectations that OPEC-led output cuts would be extended beyond June, though gains were capped by persistently high crude inventories.” (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil-idUSKBN16S040). With extending the deal, OPEC may find compliance level lower, mainly from Iran, Iraq and non-OPEC Russia. (http://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/The-Single-Biggest-Threat-To-An-OPEC-Deal-Extension.html) - the advantage of OPEC extending the deal is dependent on all members and non-members agreeing to cut and the possibility of deepening cuts.

On the day of the OPEC deal, Nov. 30 2016, the wholesale spot price for Brent crude closed at $47.95/b, on the 23rd February 2017, the closing spot price was $55.82. (eia.gov). I think it’s likely that the spot price for Brent crude will rise in the short-term, as long as OPEC members are in compliance with the deal, but I think it’s unlikely that it will break the $60/b mark, partly due to the current situation of the US oil market.  Since the OPEC cut the Brent/Dubai spread has narrowed, making middle eastern crude oil more expensive. “North Sea crude oil has been in demand from Asian buyers, in part due to OPEC’s decision to curb its production, which has reduced the price premium between North Sea crudes and Middle Eastern crudes” (platts.com)  The closing price in December 2017 is largely dependent on what OPEC will do after the initial 6 month production cut ends in June. According to an article from Reuters: “OPEC could extend the pact or apply deeper cuts from July if global crude inventories fail to drop enough” (http://uk.reuters.com/article/global-oil-idUKL4N1G507S). I’m sure it will become clear, eventually, what OPEC is justifying as “enough”, but some sort of transition phase would be needed in order to keep oil prices relatively stable, otherwise going from having production cuts to no cuts in June would cause a surge of oil into the market leading to the building of inventories again.  Crude oil prices are also dependent on the future of US output and the potential impact it could have on offsetting the OPEC deal, hence leading to a drop in oil prices: “Oil prices rose on Monday, but gains were minimal as investors gauged whether an increase in US drilling and record stockpiles would undermine efforts by producers to cut output and bring the market into balance” (http://uk.reuters.com/article/global-oil-idUKL4N1G507S).  Also need to take into consideration the general trend of supply and demand. The spot price of Brent crude will be affected during the third quarter: “It [3Q] is when most North sea producers undertake maintenance, which cuts the output of Brent and other grades during the summer.” (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec-kemp-idUSKBN15T2BV). As long as demand is still there, decreasing supply would increase the spot price for Brent crude, however, this would then lead to a decrease in oil price in the 4Q as oil fields come back online and production increases again.
